attribution: Library and University Collections, The University of Edinburgh

metadata.value: This striking view of Cairo, one of the few non-European cities depicted in the atlas, highlights elaborate details including the Great Pyramids, the Sphinx of Giza and the River Nile.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Town views of four strategic port cities on the Portuguese spice route: Aden on the Red Sea, Mombaza (Mombasa) in present day Kenya, Quiloa (Kilwa) on the Tanzanian coast and Cefala (Sofala) in Mozambique.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: This plan view of Mediolanum (Milan) conveys the city’s distinctively regular layout, developed in the 16th and 17th centuries as its medieval fortifications were replaced with formidable, bastion-like city walls.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: This bird’s eye view of Augsburg conveys the city’s unusual shape and highlights the famous Fuggerei district, the Church of St Peter am Perlach, the town hall and cathedral.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Impressive view of Colonia Agrippina (Cologne), one of the great urban centres of 16th century Europe. The streets are laid out within the city’s fortifications, and a vast fleet of vessels is docked on the Rhine.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: View from the south west of the powerful trading city of Francofordiana Ad Mo (Frankfurt am Main), a vital economic centre and trade hub since Roman times.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Bird’s eye perspective in plan form of Argentoratum (Strasbourg). Blocks of houses are markedly contracted in favour of the broad streets, squares and the city’s imposing 142 metre cathedral tower.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Spectacular view of the Belgian port of Anverpia (Antwerp) on the River Scheldt. Prominent in the foreground is the star-shaped citadel built by the Duke of Alva in 1567.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: This magnificent engraving of Leodium (Liege) presents the city on the Meuse river, which flows through a striking landscape of gentle hills, sturdy trees and fertile fields.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: The earliest surviving plan of Londinum (London), presenting the city much as it would have appeared at the time of Shakespeare. Key locations, including ‘South Wark’, ‘The Towre’ and ‘Blak Frers’, are clearly visible.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Civatates Orbis Terrarum, Inside Front Cover

metadata.value: Views of the great capitals of Mexico and Cusco at the time of the Spanish conquest: the only depictions of cities of the New World in the Civatates Orbis Terrarum.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Depiction of Rhodus (Rhodes Town) and its distinctive three-layered defensive walls. Site of the 30 metre high Colossus of Rhodes, which was destroyed in an earthquake in 226BC.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: The city of Parma, divided by the river of the same name, with the imposing Romanesque Cathedral of the Ascension of the Virgin prominent on the right bank.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Schematic drawing of Malta showing its strongly fortified harbour, including the imposing Fort of St Elmo, Fort of St Angelo and the star-shaped Fort of St Michael.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Famaugusta (Famagusta), an important fortified city on Cyprus, is shown here in bird’s eye format. Its towers, bulwarks and double walls are clearly displayed and various ships sit at anchor in the harbour.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Georg Braun (1541-1622) edited the Civitates Orbis Terrarum between 1572 and 1617. This great city atlas contained 546 prospects, bird-eye views and map views of cities from all over the world. Apart from its topographical value, these maps are also a great record of the domestic life of the period. Figures in local dress were added to the maps, along with heraldic coats of arms, town and rural scenes, land and water transport and public buildings. These depictions were accompanied by Braun's printed account of the town's history, situation and commerce. This image is of a map of London.
metadata.label: Description

label: -P-15-33
